importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, marking a key moment in the 2025 postseason baseball season, specifically Game 4 of the National League Championship Series.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe from the start of the postseason to Game 4 of the NLCS highlights Ohtani's performance and the Dodgers' trajectory to the World Series.

keyTakeAways: Shohei Ohtani delivered a historic performance in Game 4 of the NLCS, hitting three home runs and pitching effectively, becoming the first pitcher since 1886 to hit three homers in a postseason game as a starter.
Ohtani's performance was pivotal in the Dodgers' 5-1 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers, securing a four-game sweep and a berth in the World Series.
This performance marked a turning point in Ohtani's postseason struggles, as he ended an eight-game homer drought and transformed from a struggling performer to a legendary figure.

Ohtani became the first Dodgers player with two multihomer postseason games in a single postseason, and the first player to hit two homers in any game with 116 mph or higher exit velocity since Statcast began tracking in 2015.
The Dodgers' rotation, including Ohtani, maintained elite pitching performance, allowing just 10 earned runs over 10 playoff games with 81 strikeouts.
Ohtani's two-way role and mental resilience were highlighted as key to his comeback and performance under pressure.

namedEntities.name: Shohei Ohtani
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A two-way superstar in Major League Baseball, playing both as a position player and pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ohtani is central to the article, as his extraordinary performance in Game 4 of the NLCS is the narrative core of the piece — including hitting three home runs and pitching effectively.

namedEntities.name: Los Angeles Dodgers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A professional baseball team in Major League Baseball competing in the National League.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The team’s success in the postseason, particularly their victory over the Milwaukee Brewers, is directly tied to Ohtani’s performance and their advancement to the World Series.

namedEntities.name: Milwaukee Brewers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A professional baseball team in Major League Baseball competing in the National League.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Brewers were the opposing team in Game 4 of the NLCS, and their defeat by the Dodgers was key to the Dodgers’ sweep and their journey to the World Series.

namedEntities.name: Dave Roberts
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Roberts provided commentary and evaluation of Ohtani’s performance, calling it one of the greatest postseason performances in history.

namedEntities.name: Teoscar Hernández
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A position player on the Los Angeles Dodgers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hernández is mentioned as a teammate who supported Ohtani during the postseason, highlighting team dynamics and shared contributions.

namedEntities.name: Mookie Betts
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A position player on the Los Angeles Dodgers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Betts is noted as a teammate who helped Ohtani during prior postseason games, emphasizing team collaboration.

namedEntities.name: Kiké Hernández
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A position player on the Los Angeles Dodgers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Kiké Hernández is cited as the previous Dodgers player to achieve a three-homer postseason game in the 2017 NLCS, providing historical context for Ohtani's feat.

namedEntities.name: Alex Vesia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A relief pitcher for the Milwaukee Brewers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vesia escaped a jam in the top of the seventh inning, allowing the Dodgers to preserve the lead, which contributed to the final outcome of the game.

namedEntities.name: Jim Tobin
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A historical pitcher for the Boston Braves in 1942.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Tobin is referenced as the last pitcher to hit three home runs in a game as a starter, providing a historical benchmark for Ohtani’s achievement.

namedEntities.name: Guy Hecker
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A historical pitcher for Louisville in 1886.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hecker is cited as another historical pitcher who hit three home runs in a game as a starter, establishing Ohtani’s feat as a rare occurrence in baseball history.

namedEntities.name: Blake Snell
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A starting pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Snell is part of the Dodgers’ pitching rotation that maintained strong performance throughout the postseason.

namedEntities.name: Yoshinobu Yamamoto
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A starting pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Yamamoto contributed to the Dodgers’ dominant pitching performance in the postseason.

namedEntities.name: Tyler Glasnow
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A starting pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Glasnow was part of the pitching rotation that allowed only 10 earned runs over 10 playoff games.

namedEntities.name: Jackson Chourio
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A player for the Milwaukee Brewers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Chourio led off the fourth inning with a ground-rule double, the only hit Ohtani allowed during his pitching performance.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In Game 4 of the National League Championship Series, Shohei Ohtani delivered a historic two-way performance for the Los Angeles Dodgers, hitting three home runs (in the first, fourth, and seventh innings) and throwing scoreless, two-hit ball into the seventh inning with 10 strikeouts. His performance included the first leadoff homer by a pitcher in major league history, a 469-foot drive clearing the pavilion roof, and the first time a pitcher hit three homers in a postseason game as a starter since 1886. The Dodgers defeated the Milwaukee Brewers 5-1, securing a four-game sweep and advancing to the World Series. Ohtani, who had been in a postseason slump, transformed into a hero, earning the NLCS MVP award. The article highlights his mental resilience, the team’s collective effort, and the historical significance of his performance.
title: Shohei Ohtani’s Historic Two-Way Performance Powers Dodgers to World Series in NLCS Game 4
